You can also use a system of equations to solve for the slope and the y intercept if you have two points that constitute a line. say you have the points (2;-1) and (0;3) This gives us: -1=2m+b 3=0m+b Here by doing this is kinda like assuming these two have the same equation, which is how you can calculate the equation of a line by just having the position of two of its points.

A negative times a negative equals a positive.  Multiplying by a negative turns the number around by a half turn.  Starting with a number that is already negative, multiplying by another negative turns it by a half turn, to the positive axis.  This means that 1 minus negative 2 is the same thing as 1+2, which is 3.  Negative times negative = positive: Turn around, turn around again.  You're facing your original direction. Positive times positive = positive: Stay put, then stay put again.  You're facing your original direction.  Now the real challenge.  What could the square root of a negative number be, which would be a quarter turn in this application? There is an answer, coined in the 1400's, and it is a fascinating milestone in the history of mathematics.

(4, -7) on its own, has no slope.  It is just a point.  Individual points have no slope, but you can have a slope between two points, or between a point and an implied point of the origin.  You can form an equation of a line out of the point (4, -7) and the slope -1/2, but it is a completely arbitrary choice to combine this point and this slope for an example.  There is no particular reason why that point and that slope were chosen.
You should be subtracting 0-(-6), resulting in a positive 6 in the denominator of your calculation.
